name: MultiConnector
shortDescription: This extension provides menus to select the differents adapters possible to connect multiplayers using THNK extension (this is not an official THNK extension)
description: General Note : still in development, with buggs, help welcome.
This extension provides menus to select the differents adapters possible to connect multiplayers using THNK extension (this is not an official THNK extension)
- General Menu (to select which adapter will be used between : Local, P2P, Gecko, or singleplayer
- detail menus for each adapter :        - Menu for Local adapter parameter selection and connexion
- Menu for P2P adapter parameter selection and connexion
- Menu for Gecko adapter parameter selection and connexion (not writen for the moment, help welcome)
- no specific menu required for singleplayer
and also Clipboard (to allow pasting IP addres)
* In your project, create the object MultiConnectorGeneralMenu and

* In your main game scene, create the object MultiConnectorIPaddressCopy (which will allow to copy the IP address of the server, and transmit it to other players who will paste it in their connection screen.
* Otherwise the buttons are self explicative, and they will start the multiplayer THNK protocols.
* The only parameter of the extension is the name of the scene where you want to start your game (single player or multiplayer).
NOTE : some buttons don't work properly yet...  and coding is stil in progress...   solo, local and P2P are working best, but not completely.

events.name: Event Structure to allow proper use of THNK extensions

events.comment: NOTE : All these comments are inspired or taken from arthuro555  in  https://forum.gdevelop.io/t/solved-finally-how-to-use-the-thnk-example-project/42386/9

Welcome to the basics of the T.H.N.K. Framework! 

Find the complete documentation on https://thnk.arthuro555.com/ ;)

This is what a scene built upon this framework typically looks like. It has code for the server and code for the client, separated. 
This is because the architecture of servers made with this framework is authoritative: the client is supposed to be "dumb", while the server is "smart". The server runs all the game logic itself, and the client mostly tries to display the latest data from the server as smoothly and accurately as possible. This is to make sure it is not fooled by a client lying: If we were letting clients for example run the platformer behavior and make them send their new positions afterwards, a malicious client could lie about the new position to teleport itself. With an authoritative server, cheating becomes very hard, and completely eliminates many forms of it.
All events related to Client MUST be located here : (Those events will not be run when built with cloud-gdjs.)
All events related to Server MUST be located here : (Those events won't trigger on the client when connected to a server.)

events.name: Message processing (collect  the controls sent by clients, and execute them by the server)

events.comment: Example of commands sent by clients and executed by server  (idealy a Function would do that, by ex : SimulateClientCommandIntoServerEvents(param=Player , NameOfCommand="right")
Example of events creating the game logic, executed by server only (since clients are only dealing with appearance and sending commands)
No events should be ran outside of the server and client blocks! This can lead to all kinds of issues.

By default, when switching to a scene built upon the T.H.N.K. Framework, it should work normally, with the framework emulating the passing of messages between the server and client. 

Regardless of the server type, once connecting to a remote scene, the objects with the "Syncchronize" behavior, and the `State` scene variable will be downloaded from the server and applied to the scene locally. The server code will also be disabled, only letting the client code running. The server will regularly send any updates to the state variable and objects, which will be automatically applied to the scene. This makes the scene essentially managed by the server. The client code is used to forward to the server inputs made on the local client, or to manage client only objects. A client only object is an object without the synchronize behavior, it can be used for elements specific to your own client, like a pause screen, your own inventory menu, etc.

The server should manage all objects that are shared between everyone: for example, a door that can be opened and closed cannot be opened for one person and not the other, that would make no sense. Or one player object should be seen by everyone, so it should be shared too. In some cases though, you will want to make an object managed by the client. Here are a few:
- Pause menu: A pause menu should only affect the local client, not appear for every player. Therefore, it should be managed and shown only on the players computer.
- Information accessible only to select players: In among us, at the beginning, everyone discovers their roles, imposter or crewmate. This role display should only be known by the player themselves, and not be accessible to others. Additionally, it is specific to the client, and not shared information. Therefore, while the role of the player should be decided and managed by the server, passed onto the client using its `State.User` structure, and the display of that role should then be left to the client.

Those were all of the basic concepts. Enjoy the T.H.N.K. Framework!

NOTE : All these comments are taken from arthuro555  in  https://forum.gdevelop.io/t/solved-finally-how-to-use-the-thnk-example-project/42386/9
